physical_appearance:This is a batik kain panjang. It is against a brown background. The kain panjang features large European bouquets interspersed with butterflies and birds. The repeated bouquets on the left and right are inverted . Floral motifs densely decorate the background.

subject_terms_4:Kain panjang
sgcool_label_text:This batik is structured in the pagi-sore format
 comprising two different but related designs on each half of the kain panjang.  The subtle differences between the two designs include the types of flowers for the buketan motif (large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies and birds) and the inverted placement of the buketan.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966)
 the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her later batik designs attest to her virtuosity in technique and inventive colour palette.  Her repertoire of tiny isen-isen motifs (filler motifs within the outlines of the key motifs) in particular
 exudes a strong sense of artistic individuality
 possibly informed by modernist designs on European printed cloths.  Her treatment of floral bouquets is also charactertistic of the undulating and curving lines of the Art Noveau style that was introduced in the northern coast of Java by the Europeans.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: This batik is structured in the pagi-sore format, comprising two different but related designs on each half of the kain panjang.  The subtle differences between the two designs include the types of flowers for the buketan motif (large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies and birds) and the inverted placement of the buketan.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966), the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her later batik designs attest to her virtuosity in technique and inventive colour palette.  Her repertoire of tiny isen-isen motifs (filler motifs within the outlines of the key motifs) in particular, exudes a strong sense of artistic individuality, possibly informed by modernist designs on European printed cloths.  Her treatment of floral bouquets is also charactertistic of the undulating and curving lines of the Art Noveau style that was introduced in the northern coast of Java by the Europeans.
